awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites: Type II - Southeastern Wisconsin I-Corps Site: Enhancing Regional Technology Commercialization
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, from the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM), extends their initial I-Corps Site award for scale up to their next phase of support for innovation and entrepreneurship. Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors. This is a proposal for a Type II I-Corps Site - Type II proposals are submitted by institutions that have already received a Type I award.

The University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM), in partnership with the UWM Research Foundation (UWMRF), currently operates the NSF I-Corps Site of Southeastern Wisconsin ("Milwaukee I-Corps Site"), which is the only NSF I-Corps site in Wisconsin. The site draws academic teams from five Milwaukee-area academic institutions: UWM, the Medical College of Wisconsin (MCW), Marquette University (MU), Concordia University of Wisconsin (CUW), and the Milwaukee School of Engineering (MSOE). This has been an exemplary I-Corps Site that: reached out across the state; launched a Healthcare initiative; succeeded in inclusiveness, particularly among women; experimented with a variety of curricular offerings; and engaged in entrepreneurship research and published outcomes of their studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In 2015, University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM) and the UWM Research Foundation were awarded a three-year grant to establish a Lean Launch training program in Milwaukee, creating the first and only NSF I-Corps Site in the State of Wisconsin. The Site was renewed in 2018 through 2021 until it became an affiliate of the NSF I-Corps Hub of the Great Lakes Region. 

The I-Corps Site of Southeastern Wisconsin has helped foster commercialization of applied academic research and faculty/student innovation for faculty, research staff and students at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Concordia University of Wisconsin, Marquette University, Medical College of Wisconsin and Milwaukee School of Engineering - Site?s academic partners. Through this collaboration, the Site has strengthened the vibrant academic innovation network of Milwaukee.

In three years, the Site?s collaborative teaching team designed and delivered an intense four-week training course (eight cohorts) and one-week graduate student boot camp (two cohorts) to 81 academic and community entrepreneurial teams with 409 participants. Collectively, they had developed and tested technology-market fit hypotheses and tested them by interviewing more than 3,000 stakeholders.

Majority of the teams that went through I-Corps training continued their technology commercialization journey through various pathways including participation in business plan- and pitch competitions; being accepted to accelerator- and local/federal customer-discovery programs; applying and receiving SBIR/STTR awards; seeking angel funding and/or licensing their technology. Several teams were able to secure more research funding to continue working on the science and technology side of their innovations. 

Since its inception in 2015, the Site has trained 257 entrepreneurial teams that collectively raised more than $26M through accelerator- and small cash funding, angel investments and federal research grants as the direct result of their participation in the local I-Corps programs. 16 teams continued their customer discovery journey through the NSF National I-Corps program and 35 new legal entities were formed as the result of the program.

The impact of the program had propagated beyond the hundreds of participants to the courses and programs at UWM and its academic partners through the new curriculum and Lean Launch activities adopted by faculty and students.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/06/2023
Modified by: Ilya V Avdeev
